data.title: 82-year-old Pope Francis becomes first Pope to write a line of code
data.content: Eighty-two years old Pope Francis has become the first Pope of the Vatican City State to write a line of code. In Vatican City, Pope Francis with three young women aged between 11-16 years, contributed a line of code to an app aimed at promoting United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Pope Francis wrote the last line of code.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: British Airways flight lands in Scotland instead of Germany by mistake
data.content: A British Airways flight from London, destined for Dusseldorf in Germany, landed over 800 kilometres away in Scotland's Edinburgh by mistake on Monday due to incorrect flight paperwork. The passengers realised the error when the "welcome to Edinburgh" announcement was made. British Airways said the pilot wasn't lost at any point, but flight took the Edinburgh route as per paperwork.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: If anyone abuses Pakistan, I will abuse them 10 times: NC leader
data.content: Asserting that the friendship between India and Pakistan should "intensify", National Conference (NC) leader Muhammad Akbar Lone in Jammu and Kashmir said, "If anyone will abuse them (Pakistan) once, I will abuse him ten times from here." "India and Pakistan should have a friendship with each other and I am an admirer of this friendship," Lone added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Went to Pak 17 times in 18 yrs: Delhi man admits to spying for ISI
data.content: Rajasthan Police on Monday arrested a 42-year-old man from Delhi for allegedly spying for Pakistani intelligence agency ISI. During questioning, he revealed he was in contact with ISI handlers and had travelled to Pakistan 17 times in the last 18 years, ADG (Intelligence) Umesh Mishra said. The accused allegedly honey-trapped Indian Army soldiers through fake identities to collect information.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak minor Hindu girls won't voluntarily opt for conversion: Swaraj
data.content: Demanding justice for 13-year-old and 15-year-old Hindu girls, who were allegedly kidnapped in Pakistan and forcefully converted to Islam, Union Minister Sushma Swaraj tweeted, "The age of the girls isn't disputed." "Even the Prime Minister [of] Naya Pakistan will not believe that girls of this tender age can voluntarily decide about their conversion to another religion and marriage," she stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: China destroys 30,000 maps showing Arunachal as India's part: Report
data.content: Customs officials in China have reportedly destroyed nearly 30,000 world maps printed in the country for not mentioning Arunachal Pradesh and Taiwan as part of its territory. The report from state-run Global Times claims a total of 803 boxes of 28,908 "wrong maps" were seized and destroyed, making it the largest amount to be disposed of in the recent years.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Fire at mosque in US, note on New Zealand attacks found at scene
data.content: A note mentioning the shootings at the two New Zealand mosques that killed 50 people was found at the scene of a fire at a mosque in California, US, police said. No one was injured during the incident, with minor damage being caused to the building's exterior. The incident is being investigated as arson and a possible hate crime.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif granted 6 week-bail by Supreme Court
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court on Tuesday granted bail of six weeks to jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif for medical treatment within the country. He was granted bail against two surety bonds of PKR 5 million each. Sharif is currently serving a seven-year jail term in the Al-Azizia Steel Mills corruption case.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Shame I'd to go through it: Trump as probe finds no Russia collusion
data.content: After an investigation found that US President Donald Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia to influence the 2016 presidential election, Trump told reporters, "It's a shame that your President has had to go through this". "It's a shame that our country had to go through this", he added. The investigation was an "illegal takedown that failed", he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kenyan teacher who donates 80% of his salary wins $1mn global prize
data.content: A Kenyan science teacher who donates 80% of his salary to help poor students has won the $1-million 2019 Global Teacher Prize. Peter Tabichi received the prize at a ceremony in Dubai on Sunday. Around 95% of the students at the school where Tabichi teaches are from poor families and almost a third are orphans or have only one parent.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man arrested over forced marriage of 2 minor Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: Pakistani authorities have arrested a man suspected to have assisted in performing the wedding of two minor Pakistani Hindu girls, who were allegedly abducted and forcefully converted to Islam. The girls were reportedly abducted from Sindh and taken to Rahim Yar Khan where they were allegedly married forcibly to Muslim men. The girls have reportedly moved a court seeking protection.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Cruise ship reaches Norway port with 900 on board, 479 airlifted
data.content: The Viking Sky cruise ship has been towed to port in Norway with about 900 passengers and crew still on board. "It was very nearly a disaster. The ship drifted to within 100 metres of running aground before they were able to restart one of the engines," police said. Rescue services airlifted 479 people before the weather moderated on Sunday.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Pak court orders government to take custody of 2 minor Hindu girls
data.content: The Islamabad High Court has ordered the Pakistan government to take custody of the two minor Hindu girls who were allegedly abducted, forcibly converted to Islam and married to Muslim men. Pakistani authorities said the girls left home in Sindh willingly to be married in Punjab province, where the minimum legal age of marriage for girls is 16, unlike Sindh.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Video shows morgue in Russia being used to store baby food
data.content: A video shared by a Russian MP shows baby food from various brands being stored in a morgue alongside dangerous chemicals allegedly in the country's Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Region. "At first, I thought that it was some kind of a sick joke, but...it was all confirmed," the MP said. "Expired baby food was temporarily kept there," the region's government said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines believes in Boeing despite crash, says airline CEO
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines "believes in" Boeing despite Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane crash that killed all 157 people on board, the airline's CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said on Monday. It was the second crash for the 737 MAX 8 since the October crash of an Indonesian Lion Air jet. All 189 people on board the Lion Air flight died in the crash.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: NZ bans downloading, sharing of mosque attacker's manifesto
data.content: New Zealand has made it illegal to download and share the document or manifesto, reportedly written by the terrorist who attacked two mosques in the country's Christchurch. New Zealand's Chief Censor of Film and Literature said any downloaded or printed copies of it should be destroyed. The video of the attack, in which 50 people were killed, was also banned.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Norway to put world's 1st wireless e-cab charging stations
data.content: Norway's capital Oslo will become the world's first city to install wireless induction-based fast-charging systems for electric taxis, Reuters reported. Charging plates will be installed in the ground where taxis are parked, which will connect with receivers in taxis and allow them to charge for up to 75 kilowatts. Finland's Fortum is working on the project with America's Momentum Dynamics.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: 5 Indian sailors return after 14 months in jail in Greece
data.content: Five Indian crew members of a cargo ship arrived in Mumbai on Sunday after being jailed for around 14 months in Greece. They were arrested in January 2018 on charges of carrying explosive material. "They were released 15 days after a court ruled that confiscated materials were raw materials for crackers and not banned explosive material," an official said.
data.author: Shweta Singh

data.title: Rocket fired from Gaza hits house in Israel; 7 injured
data.content: At least seven people were injured after a house in Israel was hit by a rocket fired from the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military said it's reinforcing troops to the Gaza border after the attack, which prompted PM Benjamin Netanyahu to cut short his trip to the US. The Israeli military blamed the Palestinian militant group Hamas for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China infuses $2.2 billion in Pakistan's forex reserves
data.content: China on Monday infused around $2.2 billion in Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves for imports and external debt repayments. Pakistan has so far received a total of $9.1 billion in financial assistance from friendly countries during the current fiscal year, as per reports. The country's foreign exchange reserves stood at $8.84 billion as on March 15.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: NZ PM orders Royal Commission Inquiry into mosque attacks
data.content: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced that a Royal Commission of Inquiry will be held into the terror attack on two mosques in Christchurch earlier this month. Royal commissions were reserved for the gravest of events and the mosque attack was one of those, Ardern said. Fifty people were killed in the shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia opens first metro to tackle rising traffic congestion
data.content: Indonesian President Joko Widodo inaugurated the country's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system on Sunday with the aim of easing the traffic congestion in the capital Jakarta. Widodo also presided over a groundbreaking ceremony to mark the beginning of the second phase which is planned for completion by 2024. Passengers can ride for free until the end of the month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pentagon approves $1 billion to build 92 km of Trump's border wall
data.content: Acting Pentagon chief Patrick Shanahan on Monday said he has authorised $1 billion to build part of the wall sought by President Donald Trump along the US-Mexico border. The amount will go towards building 92 km of 18-foot fencing, improving roads and other measures along the border. Earlier, Trump had declared national emergency over the border wall demand.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Trump didn't conspire with Russia for 2016 elections: Mueller report
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not find that Donald Trump or his campaign schemed with Russian efforts to interfere in the 2016 presidential election, according to a summary released on Sunday. "The Special Counsel states that 'while this report doesn't conclude that the President committed a crime, it also doesn't exonerate him'," Attorney General William Barr's letter to lawmakers stated.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Israel strikes Hamas targets in Gaza after rocket attack
data.content: Israel began carrying out strikes on Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip on Monday, hours after seven people were injured in a rocket attack near Tel Aviv. Hamas fired at least 30 rockets towards Israel in response to the strikes, the Israel Defense Forces said. Hamas said that Egypt has brokered a ceasefire between the two parties following the escalation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man tries to board flight naked, says clothes affect aerodynamics
data.content: A Russian man stripped naked before boarding his flight at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport because he believed clothes made him 'less aerodynamic'. However, he was caught by the security staff while he was trying to run to the jet bridge and was later detained by the police at the airport. As per reports, the man showed no signs of being drunk.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Virtual SIMs used in Pulwama attack, India to request US for details
data.content: India would request for details of a US service provider of 'Virtual SIMs' used by the Jaish-e-Mohammed suicide bomber Adil Dar in Pulwama terror attack. In this technology, the computer generates a telephone number and the user downloads an application of the service provider on their smartphone. Dar was in constant touch with attack mastermind Mudasir Khan using the technology.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 82-year-old Pope Francis becomes first Pope to write a line of code
data.content: Eighty-two years old Pope Francis has become the first Pope of the Vatican City State to write a line of code. data.content: Five Indian crew members of a cargo ship arrived in Mumbai on Sunday after being jailed for around 14 months in Greece. They were arrested in January 2018 on charges of carrying explosive material. "They were released 15 days after a court ruled that confiscated materials were raw materials for crackers and not banned explosive material," an official said.
data.author: Shweta Singh

data.title: NZ PM orders Royal Commission Inquiry into mosque attacks
data.content: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced that a Royal Commission of Inquiry will be held into the terror attack on two mosques in Christchurch earlier this month. Royal commissions were reserved for the gravest of events and the mosque attack was one of those, Ardern said. Fifty people were killed in the shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Rocket fired from Gaza hits house in Israel; 7 injured
data.content: At least seven people were injured after a house in Israel was hit by a rocket fired from the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military said it's reinforcing troops to the Gaza border after the attack, which prompted PM Benjamin Netanyahu to cut short his trip to the US. The Israeli military blamed the Palestinian militant group Hamas for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia opens first metro to tackle rising traffic congestion
data.content: Indonesian President Joko Widodo inaugurated the country's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system on Sunday with the aim of easing the traffic congestion in the capital Jakarta. Widodo also presided over a groundbreaking ceremony to mark the beginning of the second phase which is planned for completion by 2024. Passengers can ride for free until the end of the month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China infuses $2.2 billion in Pakistan's forex reserves
data.content: China on Monday infused around $2.2 billion in Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves for imports and external debt repayments. Pakistan has so far received a total of $9.1 billion in financial assistance from friendly countries during the current fiscal year, as per reports. The country's foreign exchange reserves stood at $8.84 billion as on March 15.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Trump didn't conspire with Russia for 2016 elections: Mueller report
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not find that Donald Trump or his campaign schemed with Russian efforts to interfere in the 2016 presidential election, according to a summary released on Sunday. "The Special Counsel states that 'while this report doesn't conclude that the President committed a crime, it also doesn't exonerate him'," Attorney General William Barr's letter to lawmakers stated.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Pentagon approves $1 billion to build 92 km of Trump's border wall
data.content: Acting Pentagon chief Patrick Shanahan on Monday said he has authorised $1 billion to build part of the wall sought by President Donald Trump along the US-Mexico border. The amount will go towards building 92 km of 18-foot fencing, improving roads and other measures along the border. Earlier, Trump had declared national emergency over the border wall demand.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Israel strikes Hamas targets in Gaza after rocket attack
data.content: Israel began carrying out strikes on Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip on Monday, hours after seven people were injured in a rocket attack near Tel Aviv. Hamas fired at least 30 rockets towards Israel in response to the strikes, the Israel Defense Forces said. Hamas said that Egypt has brokered a ceasefire between the two parties following the escalation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man tries to board flight naked, says clothes affect aerodynamics
data.content: A Russian man stripped naked before boarding his flight at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport because he believed clothes made him 'less aerodynamic'. However, he was caught by the security staff while he was trying to run to the jet bridge and was later detained by the police at the airport. As per reports, the man showed no signs of being drunk.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Virtual SIMs used in Pulwama attack, India to request US for details
data.content: India would request for details of a US service provider of 'Virtual SIMs' used by the Jaish-e-Mohammed suicide bomber Adil Dar in Pulwama terror attack. In this technology, the computer generates a telephone number and the user downloads an application of the service provider on their smartphone. Dar was in constant touch with attack mastermind Mudasir Khan using the technology.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 82-year-old Pope Francis becomes first Pope to write a line of code
data.content: Eighty-two years old Pope Francis has become the first Pope of the Vatican City State to write a line of code. In Vatican City, Pope Francis with three young women aged between 11-16 years, contributed a line of code to an app aimed at promoting United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Pope Francis wrote the last line of code.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: British Airways flight lands in Scotland instead of Germany by mistake
data.content: A British Airways flight from London, destined for Dusseldorf in Germany, landed over 800 kilometres away in Scotland's Edinburgh by mistake on Monday due to incorrect flight paperwork. The passengers realised the error when the "welcome to Edinburgh" announcement was made. British Airways said the pilot wasn't lost at any point, but flight took the Edinburgh route as per paperwork.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: If anyone abuses Pakistan, I will abuse them 10 times: NC leader
data.content: Asserting that the friendship between India and Pakistan should "intensify", National Conference (NC) leader Muhammad Akbar Lone in Jammu and Kashmir said, "If anyone will abuse them (Pakistan) once, I will abuse him ten times from here." "India and Pakistan should have a friendship with each other and I am an admirer of this friendship," Lone added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: China destroys 30,000 maps showing Arunachal as India's part: Report
data.content: Customs officials in China have reportedly destroyed nearly 30,000 world maps printed in the country for not mentioning Arunachal Pradesh and Taiwan as part of its territory. The report from state-run Global Times claims a total of 803 boxes of 28,908 "wrong maps" were seized and destroyed, making it the largest amount to be disposed of in the recent years.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Went to Pak 17 times in 18 yrs: Delhi man admits to spying for ISI
data.content: Rajasthan Police on Monday arrested a 42-year-old man from Delhi for allegedly spying for Pakistani intelligence agency ISI. During questioning, he revealed he was in contact with ISI handlers and had travelled to Pakistan 17 times in the last 18 years, ADG (Intelligence) Umesh Mishra said. The accused allegedly honey-trapped Indian Army soldiers through fake identities to collect information.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak minor Hindu girls won't voluntarily opt for conversion: Swaraj
data.content: Demanding justice for 13-year-old and 15-year-old Hindu girls, who were allegedly kidnapped in Pakistan and forcefully converted to Islam, Union Minister Sushma Swaraj tweeted, "The age of the girls isn't disputed." "Even the Prime Minister [of] Naya Pakistan will not believe that girls of this tender age can voluntarily decide about their conversion to another religion and marriage," she stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Man arrested over forced marriage of 2 minor Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: Pakistani authorities have arrested a man suspected to have assisted in performing the wedding of two minor Pakistani Hindu girls, who were allegedly abducted and forcefully converted to Islam. The girls were reportedly abducted from Sindh and taken to Rahim Yar Khan where they were allegedly married forcibly to Muslim men. The girls have reportedly moved a court seeking protection.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Video shows morgue in Russia being used to store baby food
data.content: A video shared by a Russian MP shows baby food from various brands being stored in a morgue alongside dangerous chemicals allegedly in the country's Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Region. "At first, I thought that it was some kind of a sick joke, but...it was all confirmed," the MP said. "Expired baby food was temporarily kept there," the region's government said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Shame I'd to go through it: Trump as probe finds no Russia collusion
data.content: After an investigation found that US President Donald Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia to influence the 2016 presidential election, Trump told reporters, "It's a shame that your President has had to go through this". "It's a shame that our country had to go through this", he added. The investigation was an "illegal takedown that failed", he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak court orders government to take custody of 2 minor Hindu girls
data.content: The Islamabad High Court has ordered the Pakistan government to take custody of the two minor Hindu girls who were allegedly abducted, forcibly converted to Islam and married to Muslim men. Pakistani authorities said the girls left home in Sindh willingly to be married in Punjab province, where the minimum legal age of marriage for girls is 16, unlike Sindh.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Fire at mosque in US, note on New Zealand attacks found at scene
data.content: A note mentioning the shootings at the two New Zealand mosques that killed 50 people was found at the scene of a fire at a mosque in California, US, police said. No one was injured during the incident, with minor damage being caused to the building's exterior. The incident is being investigated as arson and a possible hate crime.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Cruise ship reaches Norway port with 900 on board, 479 airlifted
data.content: The Viking Sky cruise ship has been towed to port in Norway with about 900 passengers and crew still on board. "It was very nearly a disaster. The ship drifted to within 100 metres of running aground before they were able to restart one of the engines," police said. Rescue services airlifted 479 people before the weather moderated on Sunday.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif granted 6 week-bail by Supreme Court
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court on Tuesday granted bail of six weeks to jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif for medical treatment within the country. He was granted bail against two surety bonds of PKR 5 million each. Sharif is currently serving a seven-year jail term in the Al-Azizia Steel Mills corruption case.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines believes in Boeing despite crash, says airline CEO
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines "believes in" Boeing despite Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane crash that killed all 157 people on board, the airline's CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said on Monday. It was the second crash for the 737 MAX 8 since the October crash of an Indonesian Lion Air jet. All 189 people on board the Lion Air flight died in the crash.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Kenyan teacher who donates 80% of his salary wins $1mn global prize
data.content: A Kenyan science teacher who donates 80% of his salary to help poor students has won the $1-million 2019 Global Teacher Prize. Peter Tabichi received the prize at a ceremony in Dubai on Sunday. Around 95% of the students at the school where Tabichi teaches are from poor families and almost a third are orphans or have only one parent.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: NZ bans downloading, sharing of mosque attacker's manifesto
data.content: New Zealand has made it illegal to download and share the document or manifesto, reportedly written by the terrorist who attacked two mosques in the country's Christchurch. New Zealand's Chief Censor of Film and Literature said any downloaded or printed copies of it should be destroyed. The video of the attack, in which 50 people were killed, was also banned.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Norway to put world's 1st wireless e-cab charging stations
data.content: Norway's capital Oslo will become the world's first city to install wireless induction-based fast-charging systems for electric taxis, Reuters reported. Charging plates will be installed in the ground where taxis are parked, which will connect with receivers in taxis and allow them to charge for up to 75 kilowatts. Finland's Fortum is working on the project with America's Momentum Dynamics.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: 5 Indian sailors return after 14 months in jail in Greece
data.content: Five Indian crew members of a cargo ship arrived in Mumbai on Sunday after being jailed for around 14 months in Greece. They were arrested in January 2018 on charges of carrying explosive material. "They were released 15 days after a court ruled that confiscated materials were raw materials for crackers and not banned explosive material," an official said.

No one was injured during the incident, with minor damage being caused to the building's exterior. The incident is being investigated as arson and a possible hate crime.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines believes in Boeing despite crash, says airline CEO
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines "believes in" Boeing despite Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane crash that killed all 157 people on board, the airline's CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said on Monday. It was the second crash for the 737 MAX 8 since the October crash of an Indonesian Lion Air jet. All 189 people on board the Lion Air flight died in the crash.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Shame I'd to go through it: Trump as probe finds no Russia collusion
data.content: After an investigation found that US President Donald Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia to influence the 2016 presidential election, Trump told reporters, "It's a shame that your President has had to go through this". "It's a shame that our country had to go through this", he added. The investigation was an "illegal takedown that failed", he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man arrested over forced marriage of 2 minor Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: Pakistani authorities have arrested a man suspected to have assisted in performing the wedding of two minor Pakistani Hindu girls, who were allegedly abducted and forcefully converted to Islam. The girls were reportedly abducted from Sindh and taken to Rahim Yar Khan where they were allegedly married forcibly to Muslim men. The girls have reportedly moved a court seeking protection.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Video shows morgue in Russia being used to store baby food
data.content: A video shared by a Russian MP shows baby food from various brands being stored in a morgue alongside dangerous chemicals allegedly in the country's Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Region. "At first, I thought that it was some kind of a sick joke, but...it was all confirmed," the MP said. "Expired baby food was temporarily kept there," the region's government said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif granted 6 week-bail by Supreme Court
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court on Tuesday granted bail of six weeks to jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif for medical treatment within the country. He was granted bail against two surety bonds of PKR 5 million each. Sharif is currently serving a seven-year jail term in the Al-Azizia Steel Mills corruption case.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kenyan teacher who donates 80% of his salary wins $1mn global prize
data.content: A Kenyan science teacher who donates 80% of his salary to help poor students has won the $1-million 2019 Global Teacher Prize. Peter Tabichi received the prize at a ceremony in Dubai on Sunday. Around 95% of the students at the school where Tabichi teaches are from poor families and almost a third are orphans or have only one parent.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak court orders government to take custody of 2 minor Hindu girls
data.content: The Islamabad High Court has ordered the Pakistan government to take custody of the two minor Hindu girls who were allegedly abducted, forcibly converted to Islam and married to Muslim men. Pakistani authorities said the girls left home in Sindh willingly to be married in Punjab province, where the minimum legal age of marriage for girls is 16, unlike Sindh.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: NZ bans downloading, sharing of mosque attacker's manifesto
data.content: New Zealand has made it illegal to download and share the document or manifesto, reportedly written by the terrorist who attacked two mosques in the country's Christchurch. New Zealand's Chief Censor of Film and Literature said any downloaded or printed copies of it should be destroyed. The video of the attack, in which 50 people were killed, was also banned.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Norway to put world's 1st wireless e-cab charging stations
data.content: Norway's capital Oslo will become the world's first city to install wireless induction-based fast-charging systems for electric taxis, Reuters reported. Charging plates will be installed in the ground where taxis are parked, which will connect with receivers in taxis and allow them to charge for up to 75 kilowatts. Finland's Fortum is working on the project with America's Momentum Dynamics.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: 5 Indian sailors return after 14 months in jail in Greece
data.content: Five Indian crew members of a cargo ship arrived in Mumbai on Sunday after being jailed for around 14 months in Greece. They were arrested in January 2018 on charges of carrying explosive material. "They were released 15 days after a court ruled that confiscated materials were raw materials for crackers and not banned explosive material," an official said.
data.author: Shweta Singh

data.title: Rocket fired from Gaza hits house in Israel; 7 injured
data.content: At least seven people were injured after a house in Israel was hit by a rocket fired from the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military said it's reinforcing troops to the Gaza border after the attack, which prompted PM Benjamin Netanyahu to cut short his trip to the US. The Israeli military blamed the Palestinian militant group Hamas for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China infuses $2.2 billion in Pakistan's forex reserves
data.content: China on Monday infused around $2.2 billion in Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves for imports and external debt repayments. Pakistan has so far received a total of $9.1 billion in financial assistance from friendly countries during the current fiscal year, as per reports. The country's foreign exchange reserves stood at $8.84 billion as on March 15.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: NZ PM orders Royal Commission Inquiry into mosque attacks
data.content: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced that a Royal Commission of Inquiry will be held into the terror attack on two mosques in Christchurch earlier this month. Royal commissions were reserved for the gravest of events and the mosque attack was one of those, Ardern said. Fifty people were killed in the shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia opens first metro to tackle rising traffic congestion
data.content: Indonesian President Joko Widodo inaugurated the country's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system on Sunday with the aim of easing the traffic congestion in the capital Jakarta. Widodo also presided over a groundbreaking ceremony to mark the beginning of the second phase which is planned for completion by 2024. Passengers can ride for free until the end of the month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pentagon approves $1 billion to build 92 km of Trump's border wall
data.content: Acting Pentagon chief Patrick Shanahan on Monday said he has authorised $1 billion to build part of the wall sought by President Donald Trump along the US-Mexico border. The amount will go towards building 92 km of 18-foot fencing, improving roads and other measures along the border. Earlier, Trump had declared national emergency over the border wall demand.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Trump didn't conspire with Russia for 2016 elections: Mueller report
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not find that Donald Trump or his campaign schemed with Russian efforts to interfere in the 2016 presidential election, according to a summary released on Sunday. "The Special Counsel states that 'while this report doesn't conclude that the President committed a crime, it also doesn't exonerate him'," Attorney General William Barr's letter to lawmakers stated.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Israel strikes Hamas targets in Gaza after rocket attack
data.content: Israel began carrying out strikes on Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip on Monday, hours after seven people were injured in a rocket attack near Tel Aviv. Hamas fired at least 30 rockets towards Israel in response to the strikes, the Israel Defense Forces said. Hamas said that Egypt has brokered a ceasefire between the two parties following the escalation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man tries to board flight naked, says clothes affect aerodynamics
data.content: A Russian man stripped naked before boarding his flight at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport because he believed clothes made him 'less aerodynamic'. However, he was caught by the security staff while he was trying to run to the jet bridge and was later detained by the police at the airport. As per reports, the man showed no signs of being drunk.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Virtual SIMs used in Pulwama attack, India to request US for details
data.content: India would request for details of a US service provider of 'Virtual SIMs' used by the Jaish-e-Mohammed suicide bomber Adil Dar in Pulwama terror attack. In this technology, the computer generates a telephone number and the user downloads an application of the service provider on their smartphone. Dar was in constant touch with attack mastermind Mudasir Khan using the technology.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 82-year-old Pope Francis becomes first Pope to write a line of code
data.content: Eighty-two years old Pope Francis has become the first Pope of the Vatican City State to write a line of code. In Vatican City, Pope Francis with three young women aged between 11-16 years, contributed a line of code to an app aimed at promoting United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Pope Francis wrote the last line of code.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: British Airways flight lands in Scotland instead of Germany by mistake
data.content: A British Airways flight from London, destined for Dusseldorf in Germany, landed over 800 kilometres away in Scotland's Edinburgh by mistake on Monday due to incorrect flight paperwork. The passengers realised the error when the "welcome to Edinburgh" announcement was made. British Airways said the pilot wasn't lost at any point, but flight took the Edinburgh route as per paperwork.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: If anyone abuses Pakistan, I will abuse them 10 times: NC leader
data.content: Asserting that the friendship between India and Pakistan should "intensify", National Conference (NC) leader Muhammad Akbar Lone in Jammu and Kashmir said, "If anyone will abuse them (Pakistan) once, I will abuse him ten times from here." "India and Pakistan should have a friendship with each other and I am an admirer of this friendship," Lone added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak minor Hindu girls won't voluntarily opt for conversion: Swaraj
data.content: Demanding justice for 13-year-old and 15-year-old Hindu girls, who were allegedly kidnapped in Pakistan and forcefully converted to Islam, Union Minister Sushma Swaraj tweeted, "The age of the girls isn't disputed." "Even the Prime Minister [of] Naya Pakistan will not believe that girls of this tender age can voluntarily decide about their conversion to another religion and marriage," she stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: China destroys 30,000 maps showing Arunachal as India's part: Report
data.content: Customs officials in China have reportedly destroyed nearly 30,000 world maps printed in the country for not mentioning Arunachal Pradesh and Taiwan as part of its territory. The report from state-run Global Times claims a total of 803 boxes of 28,908 "wrong maps" were seized and destroyed, making it the largest amount to be disposed of in the recent years.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Went to Pak 17 times in 18 yrs: Delhi man admits to spying for ISI
data.content: Rajasthan Police on Monday arrested a 42-year-old man from Delhi for allegedly spying for Pakistani intelligence agency ISI. During questioning, he revealed he was in contact with ISI handlers and had travelled to Pakistan 17 times in the last 18 years, ADG (Intelligence) Umesh Mishra said. The accused allegedly honey-trapped Indian Army soldiers through fake identities to collect information.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Shame I'd to go through it: Trump as probe finds no Russia collusion
data.content: After an investigation found that US President Donald Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia to influence the 2016 presidential election, Trump told reporters, "It's a shame that your President has had to go through this". "It's a shame that our country had to go through this", he added. The investigation was an "illegal takedown that failed", he further said.

data.title: Cruise ship reaches Norway port with 900 on board, 479 airlifted
data.content: The Viking Sky cruise ship has been towed to port in Norway with about 900 passengers and crew still on board. "It was very nearly a disaster. The ship drifted to within 100 metres of running aground before they were able to restart one of the engines," police said. Rescue services airlifted 479 people before the weather moderated on Sunday.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Man tries to board flight naked, says clothes affect aerodynamics
data.content: A Russian man stripped naked before boarding his flight at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport because he believed clothes made him 'less aerodynamic'. However, he was caught by the security staff while he was trying to run to the jet bridge and was later detained by the police at the airport. As per reports, the man showed no signs of being drunk.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Virtual SIMs used in Pulwama attack, India to request US for details
data.content: India would request for details of a US service provider of 'Virtual SIMs' used by the Jaish-e-Mohammed suicide bomber Adil Dar in Pulwama terror attack. In this technology, the computer generates a telephone number and the user downloads an application of the service provider on their smartphone. Dar was in constant touch with attack mastermind Mudasir Khan using the technology.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 82-year-old Pope Francis becomes first Pope to write a line of code
data.content: Eighty-two years old Pope Francis has become the first Pope of the Vatican City State to write a line of code. In Vatican City, Pope Francis with three young women aged between 11-16 years, contributed a line of code to an app aimed at promoting United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Pope Francis wrote the last line of code.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: British Airways flight lands in Scotland instead of Germany by mistake
data.content: A British Airways flight from London, destined for Dusseldorf in Germany, landed over 800 kilometres away in Scotland's Edinburgh by mistake on Monday due to incorrect flight paperwork. The passengers realised the error when the "welcome to Edinburgh" announcement was made. British Airways said the pilot wasn't lost at any point, but flight took the Edinburgh route as per paperwork.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: If anyone abuses Pakistan, I will abuse them 10 times: NC leader
data.content: Asserting that the friendship between India and Pakistan should "intensify", National Conference (NC) leader Muhammad Akbar Lone in Jammu and Kashmir said, "If anyone will abuse them (Pakistan) once, I will abuse him ten times from here." "India and Pakistan should have a friendship with each other and I am an admirer of this friendship," Lone added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak minor Hindu girls won't voluntarily opt for conversion: Swaraj
data.content: Demanding justice for 13-year-old and 15-year-old Hindu girls, who were allegedly kidnapped in Pakistan and forcefully converted to Islam, Union Minister Sushma Swaraj tweeted, "The age of the girls isn't disputed." "Even the Prime Minister [of] Naya Pakistan will not believe that girls of this tender age can voluntarily decide about their conversion to another religion and marriage," she stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Went to Pak 17 times in 18 yrs: Delhi man admits to spying for ISI
data.content: Rajasthan Police on Monday arrested a 42-year-old man from Delhi for allegedly spying for Pakistani intelligence agency ISI. During questioning, he revealed he was in contact with ISI handlers and had travelled to Pakistan 17 times in the last 18 years, ADG (Intelligence) Umesh Mishra said. The accused allegedly honey-trapped Indian Army soldiers through fake identities to collect information.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: China destroys 30,000 maps showing Arunachal as India's part: Report
data.content: Customs officials in China have reportedly destroyed nearly 30,000 world maps printed in the country for not mentioning Arunachal Pradesh and Taiwan as part of its territory. The report from state-run Global Times claims a total of 803 boxes of 28,908 "wrong maps" were seized and destroyed, making it the largest amount to be disposed of in the recent years.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Kenyan teacher who donates 80% of his salary wins $1mn global prize
data.content: A Kenyan science teacher who donates 80% of his salary to help poor students has won the $1-million 2019 Global Teacher Prize. Peter Tabichi received the prize at a ceremony in Dubai on Sunday. Around 95% of the students at the school where Tabichi teaches are from poor families and almost a third are orphans or have only one parent.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak court orders government to take custody of 2 minor Hindu girls
data.content: The Islamabad High Court has ordered the Pakistan government to take custody of the two minor Hindu girls who were allegedly abducted, forcibly converted to Islam and married to Muslim men. Pakistani authorities said the girls left home in Sindh willingly to be married in Punjab province, where the minimum legal age of marriage for girls is 16, unlike Sindh.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Fire at mosque in US, note on New Zealand attacks found at scene
data.content: A note mentioning the shootings at the two New Zealand mosques that killed 50 people was found at the scene of a fire at a mosque in California, US, police said. No one was injured during the incident, with minor damage being caused to the building's exterior. The incident is being investigated as arson and a possible hate crime.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Video shows morgue in Russia being used to store baby food
data.content: A video shared by a Russian MP shows baby food from various brands being stored in a morgue alongside dangerous chemicals allegedly in the country's Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Region. "At first, I thought that it was some kind of a sick joke, but...it was all confirmed," the MP said. "Expired baby food was temporarily kept there," the region's government said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Man arrested over forced marriage of 2 minor Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: Pakistani authorities have arrested a man suspected to have assisted in performing the wedding of two minor Pakistani Hindu girls, who were allegedly abducted and forcefully converted to Islam. The girls were reportedly abducted from Sindh and taken to Rahim Yar Khan where they were allegedly married forcibly to Muslim men. The girls have reportedly moved a court seeking protection.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif granted 6 week-bail by Supreme Court
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court on Tuesday granted bail of six weeks to jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif for medical treatment within the country. He was granted bail against two surety bonds of PKR 5 million each. Sharif is currently serving a seven-year jail term in the Al-Azizia Steel Mills corruption case.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines believes in Boeing despite crash, says airline CEO
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines "believes in" Boeing despite Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane crash that killed all 157 people on board, the airline's CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said on Monday. It was the second crash for the 737 MAX 8 since the October crash of an Indonesian Lion Air jet. All 189 people on board the Lion Air flight died in the crash.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Shame I'd to go through it: Trump as probe finds no Russia collusion
data.content: After an investigation found that US President Donald Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia to influence the 2016 presidential election, Trump told reporters, "It's a shame that your President has had to go through this". "It's a shame that our country had to go through this", he added. The investigation was an "illegal takedown that failed", he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Cruise ship reaches Norway port with 900 on board, 479 airlifted
data.content: The Viking Sky cruise ship has been towed to port in Norway with about 900 passengers and crew still on board. "It was very nearly a disaster. The ship drifted to within 100 metres of running aground before they were able to restart one of the engines," police said. Rescue services airlifted 479 people before the weather moderated on Sunday.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: NZ bans downloading, sharing of mosque attacker's manifesto
data.content: New Zealand has made it illegal to download and share the document or manifesto, reportedly written by the terrorist who attacked two mosques in the country's Christchurch. New Zealand's Chief Censor of Film and Literature said any downloaded or printed copies of it should be destroyed. The video of the attack, in which 50 people were killed, was also banned.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Norway to put world's 1st wireless e-cab charging stations
data.content: Norway's capital Oslo will become the world's first city to install wireless induction-based fast-charging systems for electric taxis, Reuters reported. Charging plates will be installed in the ground where taxis are parked, which will connect with receivers in taxis and allow them to charge for up to 75 kilowatts. Finland's Fortum is working on the project with America's Momentum Dynamics.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: 5 Indian sailors return after 14 months in jail in Greece
data.content: Five Indian crew members of a cargo ship arrived in Mumbai on Sunday after being jailed for around 14 months in Greece. They were arrested in January 2018 on charges of carrying explosive material. "They were released 15 days after a court ruled that confiscated materials were raw materials for crackers and not banned explosive material," an official said.
data.author: Shweta Singh

data.title: Rocket fired from Gaza hits house in Israel; 7 injured
data.content: At least seven people were injured after a house in Israel was hit by a rocket fired from the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military said it's reinforcing troops to the Gaza border after the attack, which prompted PM Benjamin Netanyahu to cut short his trip to the US. The Israeli military blamed the Palestinian militant group Hamas for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China infuses $2.2 billion in Pakistan's forex reserves
data.content: China on Monday infused around $2.2 billion in Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves for imports and external debt repayments. Pakistan has so far received a total of $9.1 billion in financial assistance from friendly countries during the current fiscal year, as per reports. The country's foreign exchange reserves stood at $8.84 billion as on March 15.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: NZ PM orders Royal Commission Inquiry into mosque attacks
data.content: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced that a Royal Commission of Inquiry will be held into the terror attack on two mosques in Christchurch earlier this month. Royal commissions were reserved for the gravest of events and the mosque attack was one of those, Ardern said. Fifty people were killed in the shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia opens first metro to tackle rising traffic congestion
data.content: Indonesian President Joko Widodo inaugurated the country's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system on Sunday with the aim of easing the traffic congestion in the capital Jakarta. Widodo also presided over a groundbreaking ceremony to mark the beginning of the second phase which is planned for completion by 2024. Passengers can ride for free until the end of the month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pentagon approves $1 billion to build 92 km of Trump's border wall
data.content: Acting Pentagon chief Patrick Shanahan on Monday said he has authorised $1 billion to build part of the wall sought by President Donald Trump along the US-Mexico border. The amount will go towards building 92 km of 18-foot fencing, improving roads and other measures along the border. Earlier, Trump had declared national emergency over the border wall demand.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Trump didn't conspire with Russia for 2016 elections: Mueller report
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not find that Donald Trump or his campaign schemed with Russian efforts to interfere in the 2016 presidential election, according to a summary released on Sunday. "The Special Counsel states that 'while this report doesn't conclude that the President committed a crime, it also doesn't exonerate him'," Attorney General William Barr's letter to lawmakers stated.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Israel strikes Hamas targets in Gaza after rocket attack
data.content: Israel began carrying out strikes on Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip on Monday, hours after seven people were injured in a rocket attack near Tel Aviv. Hamas fired at least 30 rockets towards Israel in response to the strikes, the Israel Defense Forces said. Hamas said that Egypt has brokered a ceasefire between the two parties following the escalation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: NZ bans downloading, sharing of mosque attacker's manifesto
data.content: New Zealand has made it illegal to download and share the document or manifesto, reportedly written by the terrorist who attacked two mosques in the country's Christchurch. New Zealand's Chief Censor of Film and Literature said any downloaded or printed copies of it should be destroyed. The video of the attack, in which 50 people were killed, was also banned.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Norway to put world's 1st wireless e-cab charging stations
data.content: Norway's capital Oslo will become the world's first city to install wireless induction-based fast-charging systems for electric taxis, Reuters reported. Charging plates will be installed in the ground where taxis are parked, which will connect with receivers in taxis and allow them to charge for up to 75 kilowatts. Finland's Fortum is working on the project with America's Momentum Dynamics.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: 5 Indian sailors return after 14 months in jail in Greece
data.content: Five Indian crew members of a cargo ship arrived in Mumbai on Sunday after being jailed for around 14 months in Greece. They were arrested in January 2018 on charges of carrying explosive material. "They were released 15 days after a court ruled that confiscated materials were raw materials for crackers and not banned explosive material," an official said.
data.author: Shweta Singh

data.title: China infuses $2.2 billion in Pakistan's forex reserves
data.content: China on Monday infused around $2.2 billion in Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves for imports and external debt repayments. Pakistan has so far received a total of $9.1 billion in financial assistance from friendly countries during the current fiscal year, as per reports. The country's foreign exchange reserves stood at $8.84 billion as on March 15.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: NZ PM orders Royal Commission Inquiry into mosque attacks
data.content: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced that a Royal Commission of Inquiry will be held into the terror attack on two mosques in Christchurch earlier this month. Royal commissions were reserved for the gravest of events and the mosque attack was one of those, Ardern said. Fifty people were killed in the shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Rocket fired from Gaza hits house in Israel; 7 injured
data.content: At least seven people were injured after a house in Israel was hit by a rocket fired from the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military said it's reinforcing troops to the Gaza border after the attack, which prompted PM Benjamin Netanyahu to cut short his trip to the US. The Israeli military blamed the Palestinian militant group Hamas for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia opens first metro to tackle rising traffic congestion
data.content: Indonesian President Joko Widodo inaugurated the country's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system on Sunday with the aim of easing the traffic congestion in the capital Jakarta. Widodo also presided over a groundbreaking ceremony to mark the beginning of the second phase which is planned for completion by 2024. Passengers can ride for free until the end of the month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump didn't conspire with Russia for 2016 elections: Mueller report
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not find that Donald Trump or his campaign schemed with Russian efforts to interfere in the 2016 presidential election, according to a summary released on Sunday. "The Special Counsel states that 'while this report doesn't conclude that the President committed a crime, it also doesn't exonerate him'," Attorney General William Barr's letter to lawmakers stated.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Pentagon approves $1 billion to build 92 km of Trump's border wall
data.content: Acting Pentagon chief Patrick Shanahan on Monday said he has authorised $1 billion to build part of the wall sought by President Donald Trump along the US-Mexico border. The amount will go towards building 92 km of 18-foot fencing, improving roads and other measures along the border. Earlier, Trump had declared national emergency over the border wall demand.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Israel strikes Hamas targets in Gaza after rocket attack
data.content: Israel began carrying out strikes on Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip on Monday, hours after seven people were injured in a rocket attack near Tel Aviv. Hamas fired at least 30 rockets towards Israel in response to the strikes, the Israel Defense Forces said. Hamas said that Egypt has brokered a ceasefire between the two parties following the escalation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man tries to board flight naked, says clothes affect aerodynamics
data.content: A Russian man stripped naked before boarding his flight at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport because he believed clothes made him 'less aerodynamic'. However, he was caught by the security staff while he was trying to run to the jet bridge and was later detained by the police at the airport. As per reports, the man showed no signs of being drunk.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Virtual SIMs used in Pulwama attack, India to request US for details
data.content: India would request for details of a US service provider of 'Virtual SIMs' used by the Jaish-e-Mohammed suicide bomber Adil Dar in Pulwama terror attack. In this technology, the computer generates a telephone number and the user downloads an application of the service provider on their smartphone. Dar was in constant touch with attack mastermind Mudasir Khan using the technology.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 82-year-old Pope Francis becomes first Pope to write a line of code
data.content: Eighty-two years old Pope Francis has become the first Pope of the Vatican City State to write a line of code. In Vatican City, Pope Francis with three young women aged between 11-16 years, contributed a line of code to an app aimed at promoting United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Pope Francis wrote the last line of code.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: British Airways flight lands in Scotland instead of Germany by mistake
data.content: A British Airways flight from London, destined for Dusseldorf in Germany, landed over 800 kilometres away in Scotland's Edinburgh by mistake on Monday due to incorrect flight paperwork. The passengers realised the error when the "welcome to Edinburgh" announcement was made. British Airways said the pilot wasn't lost at any point, but flight took the Edinburgh route as per paperwork.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: If anyone abuses Pakistan, I will abuse them 10 times: NC leader
data.content: Asserting that the friendship between India and Pakistan should "intensify", National Conference (NC) leader Muhammad Akbar Lone in Jammu and Kashmir said, "If anyone will abuse them (Pakistan) once, I will abuse him ten times from here." "India and Pakistan should have a friendship with each other and I am an admirer of this friendship," Lone added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Went to Pak 17 times in 18 yrs: Delhi man admits to spying for ISI
data.content: Rajasthan Police on Monday arrested a 42-year-old man from Delhi for allegedly spying for Pakistani intelligence agency ISI. During questioning, he revealed he was in contact with ISI handlers and had travelled to Pakistan 17 times in the last 18 years, ADG (Intelligence) Umesh Mishra said. The accused allegedly honey-trapped Indian Army soldiers through fake identities to collect information.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak minor Hindu girls won't voluntarily opt for conversion: Swaraj
data.content: Demanding justice for 13-year-old and 15-year-old Hindu girls, who were allegedly kidnapped in Pakistan and forcefully converted to Islam, Union Minister Sushma Swaraj tweeted, "The age of the girls isn't disputed." "Even the Prime Minister [of] Naya Pakistan will not believe that girls of this tender age can voluntarily decide about their conversion to another religion and marriage," she stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: China destroys 30,000 maps showing Arunachal as India's part: Report
data.content: Customs officials in China have reportedly destroyed nearly 30,000 world maps printed in the country for not mentioning Arunachal Pradesh and Taiwan as part of its territory. The report from state-run Global Times claims a total of 803 boxes of 28,908 "wrong maps" were seized and destroyed, making it the largest amount to be disposed of in the recent years.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Kenyan teacher who donates 80% of his salary wins $1mn global prize
data.content: A Kenyan science teacher who donates 80% of his salary to help poor students has won the $1-million 2019 Global Teacher Prize. Peter Tabichi received the prize at a ceremony in Dubai on Sunday. Around 95% of the students at the school where Tabichi teaches are from poor families and almost a third are orphans or have only one parent.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Video shows morgue in Russia being used to store baby food
data.content: A video shared by a Russian MP shows baby food from various brands being stored in a morgue alongside dangerous chemicals allegedly in the country's Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Region. "At first, I thought that it was some kind of a sick joke, but...it was all confirmed," the MP said. "Expired baby food was temporarily kept there," the region's government said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Fire at mosque in US, note on New Zealand attacks found at scene
data.content: A note mentioning the shootings at the two New Zealand mosques that killed 50 people was found at the scene of a fire at a mosque in California, US, police said. No one was injured during the incident, with minor damage being caused to the building's exterior. The incident is being investigated as arson and a possible hate crime.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak court orders government to take custody of 2 minor Hindu girls
data.content: The Islamabad High Court has ordered the Pakistan government to take custody of the two minor Hindu girls who were allegedly abducted, forcibly converted to Islam and married to Muslim men. Pakistani authorities said the girls left home in Sindh willingly to be married in Punjab province, where the minimum legal age of marriage for girls is 16, unlike Sindh.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines believes in Boeing despite crash, says airline CEO
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines "believes in" Boeing despite Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane crash that killed all 157 people on board, the airline's CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said on Monday. It was the second crash for the 737 MAX 8 since the October crash of an Indonesian Lion Air jet. All 189 people on board the Lion Air flight died in the crash.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Cruise ship reaches Norway port with 900 on board, 479 airlifted
data.content: The Viking Sky cruise ship has been towed to port in Norway with about 900 passengers and crew still on board. "It was very nearly a disaster. The ship drifted to within 100 metres of running aground before they were able to restart one of the engines," police said. Rescue services airlifted 479 people before the weather moderated on Sunday.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Man arrested over forced marriage of 2 minor Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: Pakistani authorities have arrested a man suspected to have assisted in performing the wedding of two minor Pakistani Hindu girls, who were allegedly abducted and forcefully converted to Islam. The girls were reportedly abducted from Sindh and taken to Rahim Yar Khan where they were allegedly married forcibly to Muslim men. The girls have reportedly moved a court seeking protection.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Shame I'd to go through it: Trump as probe finds no Russia collusion
data.content: After an investigation found that US President Donald Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia to influence the 2016 presidential election, Trump told reporters, "It's a shame that your President has had to go through this". "It's a shame that our country had to go through this", he added. The investigation was an "illegal takedown that failed", he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif granted 6 week-bail by Supreme Court
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court on Tuesday granted bail of six weeks to jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif for medical treatment within the country. He was granted bail against two surety bonds of PKR 5 million each. Sharif is currently serving a seven-year jail term in the Al-Azizia Steel Mills corruption case.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: NZ bans downloading, sharing of mosque attacker's manifesto
data.content: New Zealand has made it illegal to download and share the document or manifesto, reportedly written by the terrorist who attacked two mosques in the country's Christchurch. data.content: Customs officials in China have reportedly destroyed nearly 30,000 world maps printed in the country for not mentioning Arunachal Pradesh and Taiwan as part of its territory. The report from state-run Global Times claims a total of 803 boxes of 28,908 "wrong maps" were seized and destroyed, making it the largest amount to be disposed of in the recent years.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Kenyan teacher who donates 80% of his salary wins $1mn global prize
data.content: A Kenyan science teacher who donates 80% of his salary to help poor students has won the $1-million 2019 Global Teacher Prize. Peter Tabichi received the prize at a ceremony in Dubai on Sunday. Around 95% of the students at the school where Tabichi teaches are from poor families and almost a third are orphans or have only one parent.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Video shows morgue in Russia being used to store baby food
data.content: A video shared by a Russian MP shows baby food from various brands being stored in a morgue alongside dangerous chemicals allegedly in the country's Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Region. "At first, I thought that it was some kind of a sick joke, but...it was all confirmed," the MP said. "Expired baby food was temporarily kept there," the region's government said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Shame I'd to go through it: Trump as probe finds no Russia collusion
data.content: After an investigation found that US President Donald Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia to influence the 2016 presidential election, Trump told reporters, "It's a shame that your President has had to go through this". "It's a shame that our country had to go through this", he added. The investigation was an "illegal takedown that failed", he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak court orders government to take custody of 2 minor Hindu girls
data.content: The Islamabad High Court has ordered the Pakistan government to take custody of the two minor Hindu girls who were allegedly abducted, forcibly converted to Islam and married to Muslim men. Pakistani authorities said the girls left home in Sindh willingly to be married in Punjab province, where the minimum legal age of marriage for girls is 16, unlike Sindh.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif granted 6 week-bail by Supreme Court
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court on Tuesday granted bail of six weeks to jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif for medical treatment within the country. He was granted bail against two surety bonds of PKR 5 million each. Sharif is currently serving a seven-year jail term in the Al-Azizia Steel Mills corruption case.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man arrested over forced marriage of 2 minor Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: Pakistani authorities have arrested a man suspected to have assisted in performing the wedding of two minor Pakistani Hindu girls, who were allegedly abducted and forcefully converted to Islam. The girls were reportedly abducted from Sindh and taken to Rahim Yar Khan where they were allegedly married forcibly to Muslim men. The girls have reportedly moved a court seeking protection.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines believes in Boeing despite crash, says airline CEO
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines "believes in" Boeing despite Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane crash that killed all 157 people on board, the airline's CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said on Monday. It was the second crash for the 737 MAX 8 since the October crash of an Indonesian Lion Air jet. All 189 people on board the Lion Air flight died in the crash.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Cruise ship reaches Norway port with 900 on board, 479 airlifted
data.content: The Viking Sky cruise ship has been towed to port in Norway with about 900 passengers and crew still on board. "It was very nearly a disaster. The ship drifted to within 100 metres of running aground before they were able to restart one of the engines," police said. Rescue services airlifted 479 people before the weather moderated on Sunday.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Fire at mosque in US, note on New Zealand attacks found at scene
data.content: A note mentioning the shootings at the two New Zealand mosques that killed 50 people was found at the scene of a fire at a mosque in California, US, police said. No one was injured during the incident, with minor damage being caused to the building's exterior. The incident is being investigated as arson and a possible hate crime.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: NZ bans downloading, sharing of mosque attacker's manifesto
data.content: New Zealand has made it illegal to download and share the document or manifesto, reportedly written by the terrorist who attacked two mosques in the country's Christchurch. New Zealand's Chief Censor of Film and Literature said any downloaded or printed copies of it should be destroyed. The video of the attack, in which 50 people were killed, was also banned.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Norway to put world's 1st wireless e-cab charging stations
data.content: Norway's capital Oslo will become the world's first city to install wireless induction-based fast-charging systems for electric taxis, Reuters reported. Charging plates will be installed in the ground where taxis are parked, which will connect with receivers in taxis and allow them to charge for up to 75 kilowatts. Finland's Fortum is working on the project with America's Momentum Dynamics.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: 5 Indian sailors return after 14 months in jail in Greece
data.content: Five Indian crew members of a cargo ship arrived in Mumbai on Sunday after being jailed for around 14 months in Greece. They were arrested in January 2018 on charges of carrying explosive material. "They were released 15 days after a court ruled that confiscated materials were raw materials for crackers and not banned explosive material," an official said.
data.author: Shweta Singh

data.title: China infuses $2.2 billion in Pakistan's forex reserves
data.content: China on Monday infused around $2.2 billion in Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves for imports and external debt repayments. Pakistan has so far received a total of $9.1 billion in financial assistance from friendly countries during the current fiscal year, as per reports. The country's foreign exchange reserves stood at $8.84 billion as on March 15.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: NZ PM orders Royal Commission Inquiry into mosque attacks
data.content: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced that a Royal Commission of Inquiry will be held into the terror attack on two mosques in Christchurch earlier this month. Royal commissions were reserved for the gravest of events and the mosque attack was one of those, Ardern said. Fifty people were killed in the shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia opens first metro to tackle rising traffic congestion
data.content: Indonesian President Joko Widodo inaugurated the country's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system on Sunday with the aim of easing the traffic congestion in the capital Jakarta. Widodo also presided over a groundbreaking ceremony to mark the beginning of the second phase which is planned for completion by 2024. Passengers can ride for free until the end of the month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Rocket fired from Gaza hits house in Israel; 7 injured
data.content: At least seven people were injured after a house in Israel was hit by a rocket fired from the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military said it's reinforcing troops to the Gaza border after the attack, which prompted PM Benjamin Netanyahu to cut short his trip to the US. The Israeli military blamed the Palestinian militant group Hamas for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump didn't conspire with Russia for 2016 elections: Mueller report
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not find that Donald Trump or his campaign schemed with Russian efforts to interfere in the 2016 presidential election, according to a summary released on Sunday. "The Special Counsel states that 'while this report doesn't conclude that the President committed a crime, it also doesn't exonerate him'," Attorney General William Barr's letter to lawmakers stated.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Pentagon approves $1 billion to build 92 km of Trump's border wall
data.content: Acting Pentagon chief Patrick Shanahan on Monday said he has authorised $1 billion to build part of the wall sought by President Donald Trump along the US-Mexico border. The amount will go towards building 92 km of 18-foot fencing, improving roads and other measures along the border. Earlier, Trump had declared national emergency over the border wall demand.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Israel strikes Hamas targets in Gaza after rocket attack
data.content: Israel began carrying out strikes on Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip on Monday, hours after seven people were injured in a rocket attack near Tel Aviv. Hamas fired at least 30 rockets towards Israel in response to the strikes, the Israel Defense Forces said. Hamas said that Egypt has brokered a ceasefire between the two parties following the escalation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man tries to board flight naked, says clothes affect aerodynamics
data.content: A Russian man stripped naked before boarding his flight at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport because he believed clothes made him 'less aerodynamic'. However, he was caught by the security staff while he was trying to run to the jet bridge and was later detained by the police at the airport. As per reports, the man showed no signs of being drunk.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Virtual SIMs used in Pulwama attack, India to request US for details
data.content: India would request for details of a US service provider of 'Virtual SIMs' used by the Jaish-e-Mohammed suicide bomber Adil Dar in Pulwama terror attack. In this technology, the computer generates a telephone number and the user downloads an application of the service provider on their smartphone. Dar was in constant touch with attack mastermind Mudasir Khan using the technology.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 82-year-old Pope Francis becomes first Pope to write a line of code
data.content: Eighty-two years old Pope Francis has become the first Pope of the Vatican City State to write a line of code. In Vatican City, Pope Francis with three young women aged between 11-16 years, contributed a line of code to an app aimed at promoting United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Pope Francis wrote the last line of code.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: British Airways flight lands in Scotland instead of Germany by mistake
data.content: A British Airways flight from London, destined for Dusseldorf in Germany, landed over 800 kilometres away in Scotland's Edinburgh by mistake on Monday due to incorrect flight paperwork. The passengers realised the error when the "welcome to Edinburgh" announcement was made. British Airways said the pilot wasn't lost at any point, but flight took the Edinburgh route as per paperwork.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: If anyone abuses Pakistan, I will abuse them 10 times: NC leader
data.content: Asserting that the friendship between India and Pakistan should "intensify", National Conference (NC) leader Muhammad Akbar Lone in Jammu and Kashmir said, "If anyone will abuse them (Pakistan) once, I will abuse him ten times from here." "India and Pakistan should have a friendship with each other and I am an admirer of this friendship," Lone added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Went to Pak 17 times in 18 yrs: Delhi man admits to spying for ISI
data.content: Rajasthan Police on Monday arrested a 42-year-old man from Delhi for allegedly spying for Pakistani intelligence agency ISI. During questioning, he revealed he was in contact with ISI handlers and had travelled to Pakistan 17 times in the last 18 years, ADG (Intelligence) Umesh Mishra said. The accused allegedly honey-trapped Indian Army soldiers through fake identities to collect information.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: China destroys 30,000 maps showing Arunachal as India's part: Report
data.content: Customs officials in China have reportedly destroyed nearly 30,000 world maps printed in the country for not mentioning Arunachal Pradesh and Taiwan as part of its territory. The report from state-run Global Times claims a total of 803 boxes of 28,908 "wrong maps" were seized and destroyed, making it the largest amount to be disposed of in the recent years.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak minor Hindu girls won't voluntarily opt for conversion: Swaraj
data.content: Demanding justice for 13-year-old and 15-year-old Hindu girls, who were allegedly kidnapped in Pakistan and forcefully converted to Islam, Union Minister Sushma Swaraj tweeted, "The age of the girls isn't disputed." "Even the Prime Minister [of] Naya Pakistan will not believe that girls of this tender age can voluntarily decide about their conversion to another religion and marriage," she stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Cruise ship reaches Norway port with 900 on board, 479 airlifted
data.content: The Viking Sky cruise ship has been towed to port in Norway with about 900 passengers and crew still on board. "It was very nearly a disaster.
